title: Sudoku Basics
description: Learn the fundamental rules of Sudoku and how to play the game

steps.title: Welcome to Sudoku!
steps.content:
Welcome to your first Sudoku lesson! In this lesson, you'll learn the basic rules of Sudoku and how to solve puzzles.

**What You'll Learn:**
- The structure of a Sudoku grid
- The three golden rules
- How to fill in cells
- Your first solving techniques

**Why It's Important:**
Understanding the basics is crucial for all future lessons. These fundamental rules form the foundation of every Sudoku solving technique.

**Time Estimate:** 10 minutes

steps.title: Understanding the Grid
steps.content:
A Sudoku puzzle is played on a **9√ó9 grid** divided into nine **3√ó3 boxes** (also called regions or blocks).

**Grid Components:**

1. **Rows**: 9 horizontal lines numbered 1-9 from top to bottom
2. **Columns**: 9 vertical lines numbered 1-9 from left to right
3. **Boxes**: 9 regions of 3√ó3 cells each

**Cell Notation:**
- Each cell is identified by its row and column (e.g., R1C1 = Row 1, Column 1)
- There are **81 cells** total in a Sudoku grid

**Visual Guide:**
The grid below shows how rows, columns, and boxes intersect. Notice how each cell belongs to exactly one row, one column, and one box.

diagrams.caption: A Sudoku grid showing rows (horizontal), columns (vertical), and boxes (3√ó3 regions)

steps.message: This is Row 1 - a horizontal line of 9 cells
This is Column 1 - a vertical line of 9 cells
This is Box 1 - a 3√ó3 region of 9 cells
Cell R1C1 belongs to Row 1, Column 1, and Box 1

key_points: Each cell belongs to 1 row, 1 column, and 1 box

steps.title: The Three Golden Rules
steps.content:
Every Sudoku puzzle must follow three simple rules. Understanding these rules is the key to solving any puzzle.

## **Rule 1: Each Row Must Contain 1-9**
Every horizontal row must contain the digits 1 through 9 with no repetitions.

## **Rule 2: Each Column Must Contain 1-9**
Every vertical column must contain the digits 1 through 9 with no repetitions.

## **Rule 3: Each Box Must Contain 1-9**
Every 3√ó3 box must contain the digits 1 through 9 with no repetitions.

**Important:** These rules work together. When you place a digit in a cell, it affects:
- The entire row (no other cell in that row can have that digit)
- The entire column (no other cell in that column can have that digit)
- The entire box (no other cell in that box can have that digit)

**Example:**
If you place a 5 in cell R1C1, then:
- No other cell in Row 1 can be 5
- No other cell in Column 1 can be 5
- No other cell in Box 1 (top-left) can be 5

diagrams.caption: Placing 5 in R1C1 eliminates 5 as a possibility for 20 other cells

key_points: Placing a digit affects its row, column, and box

steps.title: Let's Practice!
steps.content:
Now it's time to apply what you've learned. Complete these simple puzzles by filling in the missing cells.

**Instructions:**
1. Click on an empty cell
2. Enter a digit (1-9)
3. The game will tell you if it's correct
4. Use the "Hint" button if you get stuck

**Tips:**
- Look for rows, columns, or boxes that are almost complete
- Eliminate impossible digits
- Take your time - accuracy is more important than speed

puzzles.title: Practice Puzzle 1
hints: Look at Row 3. Which digits are missing?
Check Column 7 to see what's allowed in R3C7
puzzles.explanation: This puzzle focuses on completing an almost-full row by finding the missing digits.

puzzles.title: Practice Puzzle 2
hints: Look at Box 9 (bottom-right). Which digits are missing?
Check Column 7 to narrow down the options
puzzles.explanation: This puzzle teaches you to focus on boxes and use column constraints.

puzzles.title: Practice Puzzle 3
hints: Start with Row 8. It's missing 3 digits.
Use column constraints to find where each digit goes
puzzles.explanation: This puzzle requires using both row and column constraints together.

steps.success_message: Excellent work! You've completed the practice puzzles. You're now familiar with the basic mechanics of Sudoku!
steps.failure_message: Don't worry - Sudoku takes practice. Review the hints and try again!

steps.title: Test Your Knowledge
steps.content:
Let's make sure you understand the fundamentals. Answer these questions to complete the lesson.

**Passing Score:** 2 out of 3 correct

questions.question: How many cells are in a standard Sudoku grid?
questions.explanation: A Sudoku grid is 9√ó9, which equals 81 cells total.

questions.question: If you place the digit 7 in a cell, how many other cells are immediately affected (cannot be 7)?
questions.explanation: Placing a digit affects: 8 cells in its row + 8 cells in its column + 4 remaining cells in its box = 20 cells total.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a rule in Sudoku?
questions.explanation: Diagonals are only a constraint in X-Sudoku (a variant). Standard Sudoku only requires rows, columns, and boxes to contain 1-9.

steps.title: Lesson Complete!
steps.content:
Congratulations! You've completed your first Sudoku lesson and learned the fundamental rules of the game.

## What You've Learned:

‚úÖ **Grid Structure**: 9√ó9 grid with 9 rows, 9 columns, and 9 boxes
‚úÖ **The Three Rules**: Each row, column, and box must contain digits 1-9
‚úÖ **Cell Constraints**: Placing a digit affects 20 other cells
‚úÖ **Basic Solving**: How to fill in cells using logic

## Next Steps:

In **Lesson 2: Naked Singles**, you'll learn your first real solving technique - one of the most powerful tools in Sudoku.

A **naked single** is a cell where only one digit is possible. This technique alone can help you solve many easy puzzles!
